page.title: 04Historic Buildings, Peterlee
page.content: Up until the 1900's, this was a very rural area. In 1821 the parish of {Easington}contained 211 houses and 1,112 people. In the time of Henry I, {Ralph Flambard, Bishop of Durham, granted the manor of{Horden}to his nephew{Richard Fitzmarmaduke. {Horden Hall,}which is a farmhouse, is one of the few historic buildings in this area.It was the manor house and dates from the time of Queen Elizabeth I. The shield of arms above the door tells us that it was at that time the property of{Christopher Conyers Esq., and was probably built by him. In 1767 it became the property of {Rowland Burdon Esq.}and remained with his family until recent years, when it became the property of the{National {Coal Board. The coming of the coal_ mines in 1900 changed the countryside.
